commit.subject: Have swift pass through non log data unoutched
commit.message:
Have swift pass through non log data unoutched

We want to host images and javascript and other non html/text log data
in swift. Previously the swift generator would always logify all
requests breaking the hosting of non log data. Update the swift
generator and wsgi application to pass through data in swift untouched
if it is not known log data.

Change-Id: I83416d120ee7b99dc68e52001262d1eb90bf1da1

parents.subject: Fix swiftclient tests

commit.subject: Have swift pass through non log data unoutched
commit.message:
Have swift pass through non log data unoutched

We want to host images and javascript and other non html/text log data
in swift. Previously the swift generator would always logify all
requests breaking the hosting of non log data. Update the swift
generator and wsgi application to pass through data in swift untouched
if it is not known log data.

This refactors the wsgi application and its use of generators a bit.
Basically adds a process step where we can either choose to filter and
format logs or pass through untouched.

Change-Id: I83416d120ee7b99dc68e52001262d1eb90bf1da1

commit.subject: Support for downloading by torrent in standby extension
commit.message:
Support for downloading by torrent in standby extension

This commit adds ability to download the image
by a torrent. The base64 encoded torrent data may
by passed along with image_info instead of 'urls'.
It uses transmission daemon to download the image.

Change-Id: I852cc6745daf545fdd68c157a366fb016c313a7d

subject: refactor kill_nonprimary_server

messages.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1:

(9 comments)

so, i lied - I looked at it :P

I've got a few questions:

1) is the healthcheck stuff after kill/start server totally new (i.e. wasn't needed before, but now its in there and twice as awesome as just waiting on the pids)

2) is there a longer term play to get rid of stop_handoff_half and replace everything with newer/better kill_xyz methods - or do we expect both interfaces to stick around indefinitely (might be confusing?)

I think some of the calls to shutdown services might not be taking into account the ring nodes of the resources the test is worried about...

if I have a container named "foo" and one named "bar" the primary servers (and there for also the handoff nodes) are most likely going to be different (or in different orders) - so either the test can use the named resources setup by the brain, or the brain can get smart enough to let some context be passed in:

    self.container_brain.stop_everything_excepting_two_primaries(container1)  

or

    container1 = self.container_brain.container_name
    self.container_brain.stop_handoff_half()

Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-swift-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/19/157219/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/261b326/ : SUCCESS in 1m 16s
- gate-swift-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/19/157219/1/check/gate-swift-docs/c22c7b3//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 55s
- gate-swift-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/19/157219/1/check/gate-swift-python27/f1aad1b/ : SUCCESS in 2m 30s
- gate-swift-tox-func http://logs.openstack.org/19/157219/1/check/gate-swift-tox-func/2a9426c/ : SUCCESS in 5m 23s (non-voting)
- check-tempest-dsvm-full http://logs.openstack.org/19/157219/1/check/check-tempest-dsvm-full/dc509a3/ : SUCCESS in 43m 52s
- check-grenade-dsvm http://logs.openstack.org/19/157219/1/check/check-grenade-dsvm/7a212eb/ : SUCCESS in 38m 53s
- check-swift-dsvm-functional http://logs.openstack.org/19/157219/1/check/check-swift-dsvm-functional/9ff8700/ : SUCCESS in 15m 23s

Patch Set 1:

(8 comments)

1) the kill_nonprimary_server() and start_server() methods i replaced had checks. i originally tried without them, but ran into failures that adding them back seemed to solve.

2) i'm not sure. having a unified api would mean changing the flow of one set of tests or the other, and i don't feel like i've got a good enough clue yet to be able to do that.

Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

1) yeah I didn't see where you removed the code from so I assumed it was new - I didn't expect it to just be duplicated.

2) refactoring piece by piece can get hairy if you don't have end goal in mind, I agree that one the other halfs of test will have to change - not sure which would be the easier more generalized way to go?  But I am pretty sure we'd like there to be one obvious way to do it - especially if the goal is to consolidate all of the various ways the tests interact with the running swift cluster so that we can define the surface area of an interface that could eventually be replaced with something else.  Maybe it's not the first thing to happen - but starting to think I'd have a better take on the steps along the way if I knew where we were going.

to take one specific test, it doesn't *really* need to keep track of the *specific* server that got shutdown:

https://gist.github.com/clayg/8c69a71ca432e929636b

^ just an idea of one of many ways we could go

Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

ok, clearly i need to verbalize the long term goals and the strategies i'm using to get there

1) support distributed rings
 - use rings to identify actual ip address (and port) of the server
 - (future) figure out how to interact with remote servers

2) (create api which) support(s) rings with arbitrary numbers of replicas / devices
 - get rid of port2server

to this end, i am refactoring to get rid of test.probe.common functions that use port2server, and trying not to write any new code that uses hard-coded ip addresses.

i got rid of one call to start_server, because it needed the port number returned by kill_nonprimary_server, which i had removed. my next submission will probably get rid of kill_server and start_server (which go together).

regarding your gist:

 # Restart other primary server
- start_server(cnode['port'], self.port2server, self.pids)
+ self.container_brain.start_handoff_half()

start_handoff_half() starts both the primary and the handoff...most of the existing tests just restart the primary and leave the handoff down. i do not know if this would affect the functionality of the tests (god help me if it makes them flakey).

Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

cool.  We should chat!
Uploaded patch set 2.

Patch Set 2: Verified+1

commit.subject: Allow the configured git-url to override gerrit
commit.message:
Allow the configured git-url to override gerrit

If the user has specified a git-url in the configuration, use it
instead of what Gerrit supplies.

Also, de-prioritize the git protocol to maximize compatability.

Simplify some error messages.

parents.subject: Add a remote url override location

commit.subject: Handle NullChange "merges" gracefully.
commit.message:
Handle NullChange "merges" gracefully.

Merge completed events against NullChanges are noops if the merger
updated successfully. We should just return and let the event processor
continue without throwing an exception.

Change-Id: I47241360e56f5964fc4a47dca0108b6b552124c9

Patch Set 3:

New patch set with proposed corrections.

About heartbeat: I'm receiving those events all the time :) It might be some home brewn extension, I will check our Gerrit maintenance.

But maybe it would be better to whitelist supported events and discard all the rest? What do you think? This would solve the heartbeat problem and similar issues with future protocol extensions.

Patch Set 3:

David wrote:
> The replication events are included since 2.9 (not 2.9.1) with [1]; for some reason we don't have a v2.9 tag on the replication plugin.

My bad, I have used git tag --contains which reported 2.9.1 (since there is no tag). PS3 now comments it is in 2.9 so it is all good.

Jukka wrote:
> About heartbeat: I'm receiving those events all the time :)
> It might be some home brewn extension, I will check our Gerrit maintenance.
> But maybe it would be better to whitelist supported events and discard all the rest? What do you think? This would solve the heartbeat problem and similar issues with future protocol extensions.

I guess if there are more custom plugins sending events, that backlist will indeed grow out of control and be hard to keep up to date.

On the other hand we have a whitelist of events we actually care about ( accountfield_from_type ) which logs an error on unhanded events.  When we upgraded Wikimedia Gerrit, the spam of error made me notice that new events were added and add to be supported by Zuul, hence the lines with a comment mentioning the version:

 'reviewer-added': 'reviewer',  # Gerrit 2.5/2.6


So maybe we can just use a whitelist and discards any non matching event with no error but a debug message.  On Gerrit upgrade, one can turn on debug log to verify whether there is anything missing (or read Gerrit documentation about stream-events and plugins).  Might make it hard to catch them though.

Patch Set 3:

Antoine, do you mean a separate whitelist or simply continue using accountfield_from_type?

Now the whitelisting is kind of a side effect of setting the account field. I'm not sure if that is the best way.

Also, it would be nice to avoid catching the KeyError every time when we receive a heartbeat. Even if we could afford the performance hit, I believe :)

Our Gerrit administrators confirmed that the heartbeat message is our own home made extension.

This means that if this other change:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/135332

gets accepted then we can abandon this one.

commit.subject: Add Functional Tests of input parameter test of normal for Multipart Upload
commit.message:
Add Functional Tests of input parameter test of normal for Multipart Upload

This patch adds input parameter test of normal status for Multipart Upload.
Add following tests.

note: add a method to each API's parameter.
      combination of parameters is not tested.

Initiate Multipart Upload
  [header] x-amz-meta-
  [header] storage-class

List Multipart Uploads
  [query] delimiter
  [query] encoding-type
  [query] key-marker
  [query] max-uploads
  [query] prefix
  [query] upload-id-marker

Upload Part
  [header] content-length
  [header] content-md5

Upload Part Copy
  [header] x-amz-copy-source
    In this parameter, it has tested two patterns.
      - /dst/src -> /dst/dst
      - /dst/dst -> /dst/dst
  [header] x-amz-copy-source-if-modified-since
  [header] x-amz-copy-source-if-unmodified-since
  [header] x-amz-copy-source-if-match
  [header] x-amz-copy-source-if-none-match

List Parts
  [query] encoding-type
  [query] max-parts
  [query] part-number-marker

blueprint functional-tests

Change-Id: Id6f1fa3bd99e80335720578e1728c46f81547cea

parents.subject: Merge "Fix Nodepool DIB Uploads to Glance w/o region_name"

commit.subject: Run tasks in worker threads
commit.message:
Run tasks in worker threads

The task manager was designed under the assumption that API requests
are relatively quick and should be serialized to avoid hitting a
rate limit.  We have found that sometimes that is the case, however,
other times, API requests may take, for example, 30 seconds to complete.
Even with a very conservative API rate target of 1 request per second,
this means nodepool is 30 times slower than necessary.

This change alters the task manager so that it causes an API request
to _start_ at the specified rate limit, but does not account for when
it completes.  It does this by using the task manager thread to
serialize the start of requests, but the requests themselves are now
performed in the calling thread.

Change-Id: I025250494e7d88b82fea4514f74f204138a14d94

commit.subject: Add trap handler for aiopcpu ssh errors
commit.message:
Add trap handler for aiopcpu ssh errors

We are seeing ssh errors in multinode setups that we haev been unable to
debug externally. Add a sit and wait trap handler around ssh so that we
can log into the machines after they fail to ssh in an effort to further
debug.

Change-Id: Ifba50320324a5ca9f5d4e7493291a961c4e0de9a

parents.subject: Merge "Fix the version of Swift that required to install Swift3"

commit.subject: Fix handling of specified invalid bucket name
commit.message:
Fix handling of specified invalid bucket name

Fix the process of _parse_uri specified invalid bucket name.

S3 returns 400(InvalidBucketName), only when PUT Bucket specified
invalid bucket name is requested.
Specified invalid bucket name in API except PUT Bucket, S3 returns
404(NoSuchBucket).

Change-Id: I03972ad77cd362fcc66db3707fac1a4e58ed54c0

parents.subject: output access log of subrequests from swift3 to proxy-server

commit.subject: Fix handling of specified invalid bucket name
commit.message:
Fix handling of specified invalid bucket name

Fix the process of _parse_uri specified invalid bucket name.

S3 returns 400(InvalidBucketName), only when PUT Bucket specified
invalid bucket name is requested.

To prevent access to the resources associated with a container that
was created by Swift and that name is invalid for Swift3(S3), Swift3
validate all requests.
Specified invalid bucket name in API except PUT Bucket, Swift3 returns
404(NoSuchBucket).

Change-Id: I03972ad77cd362fcc66db3707fac1a4e58ed54c0

Put devstack-trusty-dib image in rax

Add the devstack-trusty-dib image to rax so that we can test its
behavior in that cloud. Note that we may need additional modifications
to nodepool for this to work properly in all cases. Remove it from
hpcloud since we are done testing this image there.

- gate-os-loganalyze-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/15/122615/2/check/gate-os-loganalyze-python27/cd2eb0e : SUCCESS in 1m 00s

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

neat!

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Ok, thinking over the UX a bit. 

I think we need this to be discoverable from the logs pages, so we need some link to (download all logs). 

I also think probably we should do something like use content-type=zip... or the like and use that as the switch instead of the path switch.

Patch Set 2:

> I think we need this to be discoverable from the logs pages, so we need some link to (download all logs).

Agree, but I think we should do that separately after we've tested it out manually in the production environment for a bit.

> I also think probably we should do something like use content-type=zip... or the like and use that as the switch instead of the path switch.

just to be clear, you're saying the url would be

  http://logs.openstack.org/26/118226/1/gate/gate-grenade-dsvm/fb63ac0?content-type=zip

i don't know if it makes much difference; i feel like the current way sits alongside the /htmlify option fairly logically.  it's very minor, but '?' and '&' are always annoying for wget users on the command-line; a use-case that i imagine would be very common

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I think the main point is that /htmilfy/ isn't exposed to the user in our deployment (it is rewriten with apache rules).

We have crude support for query params such as '?source=swift' so having something like a content type would make some sense here.

I'm okay with this as an intermediate step, but have you given any thought to how this may look for logs stored in swift?

parents.subject: Fix lost content escaping for html safety

commit.subject: Add ability to download log bundles
commit.message:
Add ability to download log bundles

This change provides a small additional wsgi application to download a
tarball of logs for a single test run and related test-cases.

The idea is for a modified URL such as

  http://logs.openstack.org/download/26/118226/1/gate/gate-grenade-dsvm/fb63ac0/

to initiate a download of a file called
118226_1_gate-grenade-dsvm_fb63ac0.tar.gz which includes a copy of all
logs for the test.

There are many way to skin this cat.  To explain some of the choices

 - The logs are compressed to a temporary file which is streamed back
   via wsgi.  This allows us to set the content-length correctly so
   you get what looks like a normal download, and wsgi streams the
   large file efficiently.

 - log packages are around 7MiB from my testing.  This is big but not
   ridiculous.

 - The risk I can see here is if a unfriendly spider decided to
   request every download it possibly could.  In this case, the script
   would start returning 500 errors when it could not create the
   archive.  Due to the existing way we uncompress files for sending,
   a recursive wget (ignoring robots.txt) would be much harder on the
   server than this would be and that doesn't seem to be a problem at
   the moment (people probably do this now to get access to all the
   logs quickly).  We could partition it to use a separate temp space
   if there is a problem.

 - Probably the best alternative is ZipStream [1].  Several issues:
   the pypi version seems to come from a forked source [2], it's a
   .zip, which isn't super-unixy, we don't know the content-length so
   we get no progress.  Given this and the size of the log packages, I
   don't think it this is a better approach for now.

 - The log link can be provided in the readme stuff that gets
   displayed with the logs when this is active

[1] https://github.com/SpiderOak/ZipStream
[2] https://pypi.python.org/pypi/zipstream

Change-Id: I6741d2514ae9cfef604243b9ce7063817be1ba3a

commit.subject: Add ability to download log bundles
commit.message:
Add ability to download log bundles

TODO : finish test-cases

This change provides a small additional wsgi application to download a
tarball of logs for a single test run.

The idea is for a modified URL such as

  http://logs.openstack.org/download/26/118226/1/gate/gate-grenade-dsvm/fb63ac0/

to initiate a download of a file called
118226_1_gate-grenade-dsvm_fb63ac0.tar.gz which includes a copy of all
logs for the test.

There are many way to skin this cat.  To explain some of the choices

 - the existing log-analyze stuff happens via a wsgi app, so follow
   that lead to avoid any other dependencies

 - The logs are compressed to a temporary file which is streamed back
   via wsgi.  This allows us to set the content-length correctly so
   you get what looks like a normal download, and wsgi streams the
   large file efficiently.

 - log packages are around 7MiB from my testing.  This is big but not
   ridiculous.

 - The risk I can see here is if a unfriendly spider decided to
   request every download it possibly could.  In this case, the script
   would start returning 500 errors when it could not create the
   archive.  Due to the existing way we uncompress files for sending,
   a recursive wget (ignoring robots.txt) would be much harder on the
   server than this would be and that doesn't seem to be a problem at
   the moment (people probably do this now to get access to all the
   logs quickly).  We could partition it to use a separate temp space
   if there is a problem.

 - Probably the best alternative is ZipStream [1].  Several issues:
   the pypi version seems to come from a forked source [2], it's a
   .zip, which isn't super-unixy, we don't know the content-length so
   we get no progress.  Given this and the size of the log packages, I
   don't think it is worth extra complexity.

 - The log link can be provided in the readme stuff that gets
   displayed with the logs when it is active

[1] https://github.com/SpiderOak/ZipStream
[2] https://pypi.python.org/pypi/zipstream

Change-Id: I6741d2514ae9cfef604243b9ce7063817be1ba3a

commit.subject: Drive actions around repo creation from ansible
commit.message:
Drive actions around repo creation from ansible

The only reason we need to order puppet runs is actually because we have
two sets of data that need to be actioned. puppet itself on git* and
gerrit is not order dependent. Also, rather than parameterizing the
input git ref to puppet, simplify and actually just drive it as an
action from ansible in the first place.

Change-Id: I9c2d52c88245d3ddce2eb8156bb684468fe38fb6

commit.subject: Migrate zuul timer to apscheduler version 3.0
commit.message:
Migrate zuul timer to apscheduler version 3.0

In the current release of apscheduler the 'Scheduler' object no longer
exists. This changes moves from the legacy apscheduler.scheduler.Scheduler
to the current apscheduler.schedulers.background.BackgroundScheduler object.

Updated requirements.txt to reflect apscheduler>=3.0

Change-Id: I0b0a5107e1e1fc8c90655809ef968bd28899d99a
Signed-off-by: Gene Snider <eugene.snider@huawei.com>

The scl repo fails to install properly on my rhel 6.x box with this method.  In the /etc/yum.repos.d/CentOS-SCL.repo file you need to use mirrorlist rather than setting baseurl in order to be able to install Centos rpm on rhel box.

eg 
use
mirrorlist=http://mirrorlist.centos.org/?release=6&arch=$basearch&repo=SCL

instead of
baseurl=http://mirror.centos.org/centos/$releasever/SCL/$basearch/

commit.subject: Modify py2rpm to build for scl
commit.message:
Modify py2rpm to build for scl

When building for scl, some changes are required:
1. scl headers, wrappers in the rpm spec files to build into a
different directory than normal
2. Name the rpms differently (eg python27-X instead of python-X)
so we can recognize they are built for scl. This seems to be the
scl norm

Also add a flag to py2rpm to tell it to build stuff for scl

partially implements: build-rpms-for-scl

Change-Id: I7d92f641cab6f67c749db6ab02e41601d6321702

parents.subject: Merge "Nitpicking an error statement"

scl norm

Also add a flag to py2rpm to tell it to build stuff for scl

partially implements blueprint build-rpms-for-scl

commit.subject: Get default branch from feature.yaml
commit.message:
Get default branch from feature.yaml

This is the first step in migrating away from the existing GIT_BRANCH
implementation to a feature.yaml based one.

The current logic allows setting the default branch via an
environment variable. The default branch is already configured
in features.yaml. Getting it from there instead.

The current implementation of GIT_BASE was going to be dropped in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/153023/, this change and the
following ones will provide an improved implementation instead.

Change-Id: Ifa5a81010fb598d4af5fed2361d73fba9aa6ba88

parents.subject: Merge "Move platform check after localrc"

commit.subject: Enable by default SCREEN_LOGDIR
commit.message:
Enable by default SCREEN_LOGDIR

Enable the variable SCREEN_LOGDIR as default in
the local.conf. As a team we create and test in
many virtual machines, a many times we forgot to
add this variable, and then need it to check the
logs, when this occurs, we have to restack the
devstack again.

Change-Id: Iad5c78c1b8e9308fcbbe1b2ea61756dc1b46e658

commit.subject: Configure UEFI settings on Lenovo servers (WIP)
commit.message:
Configure UEFI settings on Lenovo servers (WIP)

This provides access to UEFI firmware configuration settings
on Lenovo servers.  Usually accessed via a utility called
asu(64), this provides an alternate path to fetch settings
from python applications without requiring interaction
with a standalone executable.

Change-Id: Id4f9438e914e1a4e4426f14e3add47672974a22b

Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages

Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

My thoughts would be that it seems very limiting to have to do each folder separately. Particularly for large installations where there may be many folders.

Guess starting question would be, if you needed to support different folders for different jobs on the same run, does the command line switch still have a use case? If it does, should it override job specific folder configuration settings (however that is defined)?

If it does, then maybe this is a reasonable starting point.

Preference though would be to see if it can be worked out as to what would be needed to upload jobs to different folders.

Patch Set 3:

Dzmitry, change I8b27f4d1d1 is an attempt to provide folder plugin support in python-jenkins.  How about collaborating on that change?

Patch Set 3:

I'm also looking at adding proper support to JJB for this since it affects how jobs should be cached and referenced since you may have two jobs named the same provided they are in different folders.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

The commit message needs some work.

parents.subject: Merge "Make 'keep_descriptions' fully optional"

commit.subject: Cloudbees Folder support
commit.message:
Cloudbees Folder support

https://wiki.jenkins-ci.org/display/JENKINS/CloudBees+Folders+Plugin
This is minimally intrusive way i can think of.
Other options - update upstream python jenkins, put folder in config, multiple config files etc will require much more effort
Examples: -f "FOLDER", or -f "FOLDER1/FOLDER2"
Thoughts?

Change-Id: Ie9128f7cfc32b30f27afce218de82f1da4cccbf8

commit.subject: Add ansible node launching - don't merge
commit.message:
Add ansible node launching - don't merge

Adding a server is currently a manual task requiring root access. We'd
much prefer for that to be able to be driven from commits in git like
everything else. Add some ansible library modules that can handle what
we want from launch_node (have been submitted to ansible upstream, see:
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/8412) as
well as a set of playbooks that can be run to create and ensure the
existence of the servers we have in our infrastructure.

To try this out:

 pip install shade shade-ansible
 git clone git://github.com/ansible/ansible.git --recursive
 (cd ansible/hacking ; source env-setup)
 cd system-config
 ansible-playbook -i testhosts montytest.yaml

Change-Id: Ica6f738b066ed834d554c87db0c29da1ad2c21b3

Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

This doesn't need to be abandoned. It has components that touch the jenkins module that will need to be submitted as a change to the jenkins module at openstack-infra/system-config.

I'm interested to see how landing these at the same time will work. I reccomend the use of 'Depends-on' and close coordination with a core.

Parts of this should be reproposed to the correct module repository now: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-infra/2015-January/002380.html

parents.subject: Merge "Add solum-infra-guestagent repo to stackforge"

commit.subject: Move some jenkinsuser bits to openstack_project
commit.message:
Move some jenkinsuser bits to openstack_project

Some of the configuration in jenkinsuser is specific to openstack's
environment rather than generic to any random jenkins slave. Let's move
those bits of jenkinsuser out of the jenkins module and into the
openstack_project module.

Change-Id: I5d22fc63042d1ecd224106ad188566136d1be89c

Patch Set 23: Code-Review-1

Awesome. So, I think instead of managing the list of repos in puppet manifests, we should do something like we do with the cgit repos. We have a script in jeepyb which generates the cgit config that we need, and then we have puppet run that. We should also make sure that we run puppet on this server before on review.o.o to make sure that repo creation happens in the right order.

Patch Set 27: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

The tool sounds cool and this seems like it will work. I'll echo what clark said about using mod_proxy.

Overall this module is very openstack specific, and it doesn't need to be. The happy path would for this to be a generic module on stackforge or github, then wrap it with a role/profile under openstack_project. That might be more work than any of us are prepared to do it. But I worry if we merge a module like this we'll be carrying it around for a while.

Overall this module takes the approach of installing and running from source. There is no installer, exec for make/build, and file resources for init scripts. Is there no way to install from rpm or some other preferred  installation path?

Patch Set 27: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Agree with most of the comments, leaving -1 for the port 80 thing.  The last time we spun up a service not on port 80 and said "we'll get around to fixing that" we never did.

messages.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages

commit.subject: Doc job specification branch: handles refs
commit.message:
Doc job specification branch: handles refs

The branch: filter of a job specification can be used to match the
branch a change targets as well as the ref of a ref-updated event.

That was introduced by 45865f3e https://review.openstack.org/14096 but
lacked documentation.

Mention job.branch handles refs, based on the documentation of the
Gerrit trigger `ref` parameter.

commit.subject: O_DIRECT: Use O_DIRECT for reading and writing object data.
commit.message:
O_DIRECT: Use O_DIRECT for reading and writing object data.

For reading, if disk_chunk_size is 4K aligned allocate a read buffer that is 4K
aligned using mmap and set the file descriptor flags to include O_DIRECT. If
there is an exception reading while O_DIRECT is set, it could be because the
seek alignment is not 4K aligned, so disable O_DIRECT and perform a standard
read.

For writing large files (>= network_chunk_size), if network_chunk_size is 4K
aligned then O_DIRECT will be used for network_chunk_size chunks. If the last
chunk smaller then network_chunk_size, then O_DIRECT will be disabled and a
normal write used instead. For small files (< network_chunk_size), if the file
size is a multiple of 4K it will attempt to write using O_DIRECT, otherwise a
normal write will be used.

There are at least two ways this diff could be improved. Currently
network_chunk_size is not known at the diskfile.py layer so for writing the
buffer is allocated at 4K then increased to chunk length when the first write
comes in (assuming chunk length is 4K aligned). This double allocation could be
removed if network_chunk_size was available at this layer.

The 4K alignment was selected because O_DIRECT requires memory alignment to
match the sector size of the underlying block device. This could be queried
using BLKSSZGET ioctl, but this seemed a bit excessive to do for each file, so
I used a fixed 4K value which covers both 512 byte sectors and 4K sectors.

Testing on a 5 storage node cluster improved read performance between 2.5x and
5x using large files. Rate limiting was disabled in the proxy and object and
client chunk sizes set to 16K. Object servers used 2MB disk and network chunk
sizes and 8 threads per disk.

Change-Id: I769680790b9549109a579d410f8a75fac745eb3d

commit.subject: Apply any URL rewriting rules from Git configuration
commit.message:
Apply any URL rewriting rules from Git configuration

The URLs returned by 'git config --get' are liable to be rewritten by Git if
they match any configured url.<base>.insteadOf rules. We have to invoke 'git
ls-remote --url' to ensure that the URL we use is fully expanded.

Change-Id: Ibc869902615df51050f857d1916a5a112079c0d1

commit.subject: Add performance enhancement for nova-powervc startup
commit.message:
Add performance enhancement for nova-powervc startup

1. Add new hypervisor cache for startup
2. Remove powervc driver dependency out of sync manager
3. Let driver list_instance_uuids not implemented to prevent nova
manager code to process "deleted" instances
4. Make driver list_instances always return empty list to prevent nova
manager code to handle "deleted" instances
5. Improve volume cache
6. Move deleted_pvc_ids cache to powervc.common.utils

Change-Id: I37b5c00479ca0b434217be4459cc2aebf6ec5338

parents.subject: fix pep8 issue on powervc driver

parents.subject: Move non-Windows specific plugins to common

commit.subject: Add support for FreeBSD in cloudbaseinit
commit.message:
Add support for FreeBSD in cloudbaseinit

In order to have FreeBSD support in cloudbaseinit, this patch adds the
following:

  * osutils.freebsd, implementing OS utilities specific for FreeBSD.

  * two FreeBSD specific plugins, createuser and enlargeroot.

  * changes to the ConfigDrive metadata manager. In order to fully
    leverage multiple platforms, some API changes were brought to
    BaseConfigDriveManager.

  * support for ConfigDrive for FreeBSD.

  * changes to the OS dispatching mechanism.
    It uses platform.system instead of sys.name, because platform.system
    is more coarse grained, yielding 'FreeBSD' instead of 'freebsd10' on
    a FreeBSD 10 platform.

Change-Id: I425c517eb7a051fd1816fc4c4a18a0bd2600209d

parents.subject: Merge "Update build requires for cent7"

commit.subject: Modify smithy and anvil to support scl builds
commit.message:
Modify smithy and anvil to support scl builds

o add USE_SCL variable to smithy
o add bootstrap_scl to smithy for repo config and package install
o modify all virtualenv, pip, and python command invocations to
  support scl and non-scl builds
o add --build-for-scl-python27 option to anvil
o postprocess specfiles with spec2scl
o pass 'scl python27' macro to rpmbuild
o tweak execute(...) in shell.py to work when stdin is None
o add standalone tool build-pbr-for-scl-python27.py to build
  pbr rpm in order to bootstrap anvil

partially implements blueprint build-rpms-for-scl

Change-Id: I475d925231604ef9c4257515d05e8e1ceaa2c53e

parents.subject: Merge "Update build requires for cent7"

commit.subject: Fix the object owner information in the response body of GET Bucket
commit.message:
Fix the object owner information in the response body of GET Bucket

In the current Swift3, return the request user as the object owner,  but it
should return a real object owner.
So, add the owner acquisition process of each object in the object list for
GET bucket.

Change-Id: I803fca0d2303134d47efcf4499b679fd0c037b4e

(2 comments)

Thanks, we definitely do need an example of SoftwareDeployments, and this looks like a nice simple one to start with.

Couple of comments re the content of the config being applied.

Also, related to my comments, I don't really get why using python is related to exit(0), you can just use exit in bash?
Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

@shardy, thanks for the comments.

Please check my comments inline.

exit(0) is not strictly required in this example, so I'm removing it. The reason I had it there is that it could be a common error where template authors failed to indicate a success to software config.

Will commit another patchset soon.
Uploaded patch set 3.

Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-heat-templates-dsvm http://logs.openstack.org/49/134749/3/check/gate-heat-templates-dsvm/161337a : FAILURE in 14m 36s (non-voting)
- gate-heat-templates-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/49/134749/3/check/gate-heat-templates-pep8/a844caa : SUCCESS in 37s (non-voting)
- gate-heat-templates-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/49/134749/3/check/gate-heat-templates-python26/e580fdb : SUCCESS in 32s (non-voting)
- gate-heat-templates-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/49/134749/3/check/gate-heat-templates-python27/60a8a60 : SUCCESS in 25s (non-voting)

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 3:

@shardy, in the new patchset (3), I'm passing in a dictionary.  That is why I proposed a change to enable script hook to handle 'Json' data type.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I'm still of the opinion that the python snippet is confusing, and the eval usage is concerning.

FWIW, I see template examples as best to contain the minimum to demonstrate the functionality, and in this case we have a config with group "script" which then has a python script exposing internal interface details of some stuff normally only considered by the hook scripts (which, confusingly, are python scripts).

So all things considered, I'd rather replace it with one line of bash.  You can use "tee" if you want to print to stdout and a file simultaneously.

Feel free to wait for feedback from tspatzier and stevebaker though if you don't agree with my opinion :)

Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

I don't really have a problem with using a python script instead of a bash script. It is not really using internal APIs but just what is available via the environment to any script, no matter what language.
Uploaded patch set 4.

Patch Set 4: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-heat-templates-dsvm http://logs.openstack.org/49/134749/4/check/gate-heat-templates-dsvm/9485a4b : SUCCESS in 15m 27s (non-voting)
- gate-heat-templates-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/49/134749/4/check/gate-heat-templates-pep8/90fa04f : SUCCESS in 27s (non-voting)
- gate-heat-templates-python26 http://logs.openstack.org/49/134749/4/check/gate-heat-templates-python26/93119cf : SUCCESS in 29s (non-voting)
- gate-heat-templates-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/49/134749/4/check/gate-heat-templates-python27/4bf93f4 : SUCCESS in 28s (non-voting)

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Ok, so regarding the template version thing I mentioned in my last comment, I see that we have in fact two different implementations for get_attr, so that's ok (thanks Qiming for pointing me to it). It still feels a bit confusing to me, but that's another issue.

The -1 is only because I was expecting to see a response to Steven's comment on eval in patch set 3. As for using a python script instead of bash, I am ok as said in my last comment.

Patch Set 4:

Well, I admit that, in general, 'eval' is a dangerous function that can be exploited.  The reason I was using it in the Python script is that I am passing in something in this form:

"{u'0': u'timestamp 1', u'1': u'timestamp 2'}"

The dict is an input generated from the SoftwareDeployments resource (Line 39).  Parsing this data structure using Bash might unnecessarily complicate the template.  That is why Python was used.  The data structure is not a strict Json (and I cannot convert it to Json in template), so the most straight-forward way to parse it is using 'eval()'.

Regarding the danger it poses to users, I'm hoping that users would be aware of it -- maybe I should leave a comment warning users of this?

Why I'm doing this?  I was trying to exemplify how each server in a group can retrieve its own slice of data based on its resource name.

Patch Set 4:

Qiming: I think you're using eval to work around a bug - the map returned from the resource should be reformatted via the input IMO, as if something is type Json, surely it's a bug if it's not parseable via json.loads?

It seems to me that there should be some format manipulation, such that the inputs are cast where possible based on the schema (e.g type of the input)?

So, by the time the json input hits the script in the VM, it should have the quoting correctly formatted, e.g '{"0": "timestamp 1", "1": "timestamp 2"}'

If you agree, perhaps you can raise a bug, then add a comment in the template warning that eval usage is potentially unsafe, and referencing the bug justifying it's usage as a workaround?

Patch Set 4:

Thanks for the clarification. I think a comment on what the eval call does, i.e. what the input and expected output is would be helpful so that people can see it without having detail understanding of other resources.

Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

Okay, I agree to Steven's suggestion so I am putting this on hold until I can fix the problem of passing Python dictionary around.

The current problem is formatting outputs, where no output carries type information.  I cannot tell whether a string is an encoded JSON.
Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased

Patch Set 5: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

commit.subject: Sample template using SoftwareDeployments
commit.message:
Sample template using SoftwareDeployments

This template demonstrates how to use SoftwareDeployments over a group
of servers.  The key points of this template are:

 - the use of '2014-10-16' as the version, or else 'get_attr' won't work
   as expected.
 - the approach to generate 'servers' property for SoftwareDeployments.
 - passing dictionary into server and extract info corresponding to
   current server.

Change-Id: I632799221d42c3e133ee1d162686cb234bd9d549

parents.subject: Refactor image writing

commit.subject: Add vhd writing support to agent
commit.message:
Add vhd writing support to agent

This adds a VHDUtilImageManager class that supports writing out tar
files that contain vhds. This relies on a 3rd party tool, 'vhd-util',
and patches to that utility.

A script to build vhd-util exists here:

https://github.com/comstud/libvhd-builder

That will clone the appropriate repo for vhd-util and build it, as long
as you have the correct dependencies (documented in the build script).

The vhd-util binary will need to be put into the following directory
within the agent code (create the missing directories):

imagebuild/coreos/oem/vhd-util/1.0

before building the agent image.

Change-Id: I24d7940040e5edc413469b434778409bbac0c8f3

parents.subject: Use poll instead of threading.Event in heartbeat thread

commit.subject: Refactor image writing
commit.message:
Refactor image writing

This breaks image writing out of the standby extension and into its own
set of classes that are exposed via the hardware manager. This will
allow different image writing processes to be added more easily (e.g.,
vhd writing -- which qemu_img doesn't fully support).

Change-Id: Ie4cd4e369dec5b0b42a83a9d7a3e6f083124f778

commit.message:

This breaks image writing out of the standby extension and into its own
set of classes that are exposed via the hardware manager. This will
allow different image writing processes to be added more easily (e.g.,
vhd writing -- which qemu_img doesn't fully support).

commit.subject: Add better comment event reporting to Gerritbot
commit.message:
Add better comment event reporting to Gerritbot

Adjusted gerritbot to be less verbose when reporting on comment events. You
can now target specific comment events like 'x-vrif-minus-2' and it will only
send those events to the irc channel. You can still target all comment events
by using 'comment-added' in the yaml configuration.

Change-Id: I71618612ab025bc1d98202c17830d737b9b34064
Closes-Bug: #1216114

parents.subject: Make proposed and merged messages more terse

commit.subject: Fix comment event reporting in Gerritbot
commit.message:
Fix comment event reporting in Gerritbot

I've made changes to the ChannelConfig and Gerrit classes to
better support comment events. ChannelConfig will parse the new
structure of the yaml files to better illustrate the event
hierarchy (Example Below).

openstack-glance:
    events:
      - patchset-created
      - change-merged
      - comment-added:
        - 'VRIF -2'
        - 'CRVW 2'

ChannelConfig.cevents holds the channel hashes for the different
comment events.

The comment_added method is changed to support the new data
structure from ChannelConfig. I also removed the generic
comment_added message since this was making the Gerritbot too verbose.
We can always add an 'all' value in the yaml to add support for all
messages but it sounds to me like this would be an unused feature.

I've marked this as a partial fix as the configuration files
will need to be updated which live in a separate repo.

Change-Id: I71618612ab025bc1d98202c17830d737b9b34064
Partial-Bug: #1216114

parents.subject: Make proposed and merged messages more terse

commit.subject: Fix comment event reporting in Gerritbot
commit.message:
Fix comment event reporting in Gerritbot

I've made three changes to the ChannelConfig and Gerrit classes to
bettersupport comment events. ChannelConfig will parse the new
structure of the yaml files to better illustrate the event
hierarchy (Example Below).

openstack-glance:
    events:
      - patchset-created
      - change-merged
      - comment-added:
        - 'VRIF -2'
        - 'CRVW 2'

ChannelConfig.cevents holds the channel hashes for the different
comment events.

I changed Gerrit's read method to dynamically call the method
associated with the event listed in the yaml file. Any reference
to an event that Gerrit does not have a method for is logged.

The comment_added method is changed to support the new data
structure from ChannelConfig. I also removed the generic
comment_added message since this was making the Gerritbot too verbose.
We can always add an 'all' value in the yaml to add support for all
messages but it sounds to me like this would be an unused feature.

I've marked this as a partial fix as the configuration files
will need to be updated which live in a separate repo.

Change-Id: I71618612ab025bc1d98202c17830d737b9b34064
Partial-Bug: #1216114

commit.subject: Add policy engine to keystoneauth
commit.message:
Add policy engine to keystoneauth

This patch add OpenStack Policy engine into keystaoneauth
without altering the external interface of the middleware
I.E: Only the internal implementation of the authorization checks
was changed, the middleware parameters and unittests
remain the same.

How does it work:
* "authorize" method were re-implemented to use an "enforcer"
which is base on the json policy format defined in OpenStack.
* All keystoneauth authorisations logic were translated into json policy
format, to ensure backward compatibly.
* No change to the middleware parameter were done for now,
when the middleware is called with its usual parameters
(operator_roles, reseller_role, and is_admin)
we pass those parameter to the enforcer, which know how to
translate them into the corresponding json policy format, and then
apply checks based on the result.

(In a next patch we would like to address the second step of the blue
print which is allowing to specify a json policy file as a parameter of
the middleware and handle authorization according to that file).

Partially implements bpauthorization-policy

Change-Id: I8d506791f22233adbc29d9aab26e08dd9c6419ef

commit.subject: Add ability to ignore in-file
commit.message:
Add ability to ignore in-file

While looking at Idd856e897ff97095fb116294a9187ff4b198fa26 I realised
that our checking is picking up on embedded awk programs.

For something like this, I think we should be able to skip individual
tests just for a single file.

To achieve this, we keep a list of tests to ignore from the command
line, and append any tests we see from a special comment line as
described in the documentation.

One change is making it explicit that tests to ignore should be
separated by commas.  We don't want to mix "|" matching in there, as
that is exposing the implementation details of the regex-search.
Documentation is updated to make this clear, and test-cases modified.

This also includes a man page for bashate.1 which also describes these
usage details, and links this from the readme.

Change-Id: Id04a84ce48546f071a26caf2a5274c4ea1904490

subject: Adding Optional Health to OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup

messages.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1:

Intended to supersede https://review.openstack.org/#/c/124620/

Patch Set 1:

This is the spec for https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/autoscaling-healthy-group

Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-heat-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/56/124656/1/check/gate-heat-specs-docs/82b3634/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 54s
Uploaded patch set 2.

Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build succeeded.

- gate-heat-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/56/124656/2/check/gate-heat-specs-docs/128b28e/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 45s

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Patch Set 2:

The point of this is to release this new resource type at least one release before we remove HARestarter so that users can start getting HARestarter out of their templates early.  I am suggesting this because there seems to be a real danger that HARestarter will have to be removed in the same release that introduces the first viable alternative.

AutoScalingHealthGroup is intended to be general enough for the current users of HARestarter but not so general to risk not being implementable in the future that lacks HARestarter.  I know of no current user of HARestarter that could not use AutoScalingHealthyGroup instead.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

It would be nicer to have some change we could make to the regular autoscaling group that would continue to be useful even when convergence arrives, rather than another weird resource type that would itself have to be deprecated.

e.g. having some way to force the autoscaling group to delete a particular member based on an alarm would be generically useful for stuff like selective scale-down, even after we have convergence.

Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

Replies in-line to in-line comments.  Plus the following.

Today Ceilometer has a dismaying limitation: an alarm action is only a URL, it can not include an HTTP request body.  Correspondingly, when an HARestarter's webhook is hit, the action code does not look in the HTTP request body for any user data (just generic stuff).  These imply that today there has to be a distinct webhook for every health-maintained resource.  I hope for a better future, but am told it is not imminent.  Which means that an interface that exposes the existing webhooks is poorly future-proofed, and a little delay will not help.

However, I think your broader point is actionable.  Rather than introducing a new resource type that maintains health, we could change the existing OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup to optionally exhibit the behavior that I proposed here be new for a subclass.  That is, we could give OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup an optional parameter that is the name of an attribute of the member type that reveals the member's OS::Neutron::PoolMember.  If and only if that optional name is provided to an instance of OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup, the asg will engage in the health maintenance behavior proposed here.  As for the timeout_in_minutes, that could be another optional parameter that validation allows only if the pool member attribute name is supplied.

Patch Set 2:

The problem this is trying to solve is the lack of a commitment to a transition period in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/121824/

Patch Set 2:

When an OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup --- which is necessarily a resource (call it R) in some parent stack (call it X) --- scales in or out, do the dependents of R in X get UPDATEd?  Yes, R can have dependents that need updating --- remember that R has attributes.

Suppose that X is itself a resource (call it S) in a parent stack (call it W).  If R scales and this changes the outputs of X, do the dependents of S get UPDATEd?

If either answer is "no", I would argue it is a bug.

Patch Set 2:

Angus made the following remarks on the older spec, which (I think) apply equally well to this one because he was (I think) addressing interface rather than implementation.

Mike I am not a fan of this as-is. But it's good to get some ideas out there. I think what is wrong with harestarter is it's "target" is not necessarily a stack. To follow what the autoscaling does better would be to have (highly abbreviated):

resources:
hapolicy:
type: a-better-ha-restarter
properties:
target: {get_resource: ha-thing}
some_alarm:
type: Alarm
properties:
alarm_actions: [{get_attr: [hapolicy, AlarmUrl]}]
ha-thing:
type: HaResource
properties:
resource:
type: server_and_some_stuff.yaml
properties:
image: dude
flavor: yum

The main thing is to "container-ize" the resources been restarted *and* force the harestarter to only point to one of these resource types.

It would be good to get some feedback from others tho'.

Patch Set 2:

I deliberately proposed a rather narrow interface for a variety of reasons.  One reason I did not expose something like a-better-ha-restarter resource type is that I was warned that there may be no close analogue of OS::Heat::HARestarter once Convergence has arrived.

A little more broadly: I chose to expose essentially no implementation details, so that we would not find ourselves in a tight spot in the future (not having a crystal ball and all).  I tried to propose an interface that talks only about function, without detailing how it gets done.  Yes, that makes the proposal limited in scope.  Even so, it is pretty broad.  It is enough for the users of HARestarter that I know of, so I think the scope limitation is not a problem.

In fact, following Zane's line of thinking, I could even argue that merging this functionality into the modern scaling groups is the "other shoe" that we have been waiting to drop ever since we introduced scaling groups whose member type is not necessarily a Compute instance: with a fully general member type, a scaling group resource type can not be expected to understand how to test the member's health (including application function, not just resource existence) --- what is needed is an explicit connection to something that *does* know how to test a member's health.

Patch Set 2:

Again, the obsoleted spec is at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/124620/

There you can read Angus' remark with proper white space.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Agree with Zane that ideally this would just be an enhancement of the existing AutoScalingGroup. This would be of general benefit for ASG, so it would be more than an interim new resource type. From your comment in reply to Zane's it seem you think this is doable, right?

Patch Set 2:

Yes, I think that is doable.  I would have code for it now, except that my attention is being focused on other stuff right now.

Patch Set 2:

Oh dang, see https://bugs.launchpad.net/heat/+bug/1326721

The bug description is wrongly worded, it describes a fix rather than the bug.  The bug is that Heat can not create an alarm that filters Samples based on anything (such as resource ID) other than metadata.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I think this needs more discussion - Summit session? https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/kilo-heat-summit-topics

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Answered the last of the outstanding comments inline.  Preparing code, along the lines discussed: adding optional health maintenance to OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup, building on my fix to https://bugs.launchpad.net/heat/+bug/1326721 .

Angus, if you'd like to indicate the outstanding issues that concern you, I'd be interested.

Thanks

Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Revised and extended one remark inline.

Patch Set 2:

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127884/ for an implementation that is intended to follow what I think the discussion has converged on.  Yeah, the spec needs to be updated.
Uploaded patch set 3.

Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-heat-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/56/124656/3/check/gate-heat-specs-docs/674d69f/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 35s

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Mike: Would it be possible to remove all the repeated statements about HARestarter and how we got to this requirement, and just focus on the actual feature, e.g specific details of how we can modify AutoScalingGroup to meet your needs?

The deprecation strategy of HARestarter is really unrelated to this spec, other than that it may provide a solution for folks to migrate to, so I for one find all the relentless references to HARestarter as something of a distraction to the issue at hand.
Uploaded patch set 4.

Patch Set 4:

I tried to refocus as I think Steven Hardy suggested.  Even so, HARestarter shows up as part of the problem --- but not really the same problem.

Patch Set 4: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-heat-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/56/124656/4/check/gate-heat-specs-docs/37289ac/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 59s

Patch Set 4:

(5 comments)

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

So, to clarify, we need a replacement for deprecated HARestarter, so you're proposing replacing it with a nested template solution based on.... HARestarter!

Doh!

I'm totally +1 on addressing this requirement but there has to be a better way than this.

I think the general pattern sounds fine (Neutron health metric, ceilometer alarm, ASG), it's just the AutoScalingGroup resource implementation which I personally view as completely not the direction we want to be headed.

Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)

Replies to Thomas in-line.  For Steven:

Are you objecting only to the implementation here, or also to the interface?  I think the interface here is reasonably good, and is something we could be willing to maintain in the long term --- as the implementation improves when the necessary other work gets done.

Do you know a better implementation that could be used today?  If so, can you please exhibit an outline?

Or maybe you are recommending an approach that can not be followed with today's code, but you hope the necessary gaps can be filled soon.  In that case I would also be interested in seeing an outline of the asg-with-health implementation in that anticipated future.

Patch Set 4:

> Are you objecting only to the implementation here, or also to the interface?

It's mostly the implementation which I'm quite strongly opposed to.

Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 4:

As a comment to Mike's and Steven's discussion: I think there are two major points here: (1) we need agreement on the interface, and (2) we need agreement on the implementation, right?

So (1) looks generally ok with me; we can talk about details regarding property naming etc.

Re (2), I think there is still some more discussion needed.

Does that distinction make sense, and if yes, is there consensus on at least (1)?

Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

One in-line reply to Thomas.  Also, overall, on the interface vs implementation thing:

If there are objections to the interface, I would like to understand them.  I have understood Thomas to make remarks about interface, and Steven to have made remarks about implementation plus one remark about the scope in the introductory paragraph.  That remark (if I understand it correctly) is not really challenging the scope, just challenging my statement of it.  Steven, if you have concerns about the interface, can you please help me understand them?

If there are objections to the initial implementation, I would like to see a viable alternative that works now.  I am happy to discuss better implementations for the future, but do not think they need to hold up acceptance of a change with an implementation that works currently.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

> if you have concerns about the interface, can you please help me understand them?

My concern is that the interface may not make sense when we are in a position to remove this hack, either via coming up with a better pre-convergence solution, or via continuous convergence.

As Thomas Herve has mentioned, what you propose is already possible, we don't need to bake it into the resource implementation to make it more possible.

The main driver behind this does appear to be removing some inconvenient template boilerplate, rather than really implementing anything new, so as therve has asked, have you looked into putting the repeated stuff into a provider template?

Also, as mentioned by Thomas, the implicit dependency between the ASG and LB in your new interface is not ideal - I'd far rather we figured out a solution where "health" can be determined via a user-configurable alarm which can be triggered by anything (e.g an agent in the VM monitoring application health), not just the LB health monitor.

> I would like to see a viable alternative that works now.

Sure, so would I, but IMO it makes more long-term sense for the project if we work on identifying a viable, maintainable solution that can work soon (e.g in the Kilo timeframe), particularly given that this solution is already working for you, albeit via a different interface.

Patch Set 4:

Yes, I tried to find a way to do it with a provider template, and could not.  Following are some of the difficulties I ran into.

* I can not write "resource_name: {get_param: resource_def}" in the resources section of a HOT.

* I can not write a template that reads the configured averaging period.

* I can not write a provider template that includes or omits a clause based on whether or what value the user gave to a property of the facade.  (OK, I have not implemented that part yet, but it is in the spec and should be added to the implementation.)

* I can not write a template that reads any clock or does arithmetic.  The implication is that I can not write a template that computes when the grace period for a given group member expires.  Ceilometer does not have the concept of a grace period built into its alarm concept, but it does allow the client to specify a start time (which the client has to calculate).  The concept of a grace period is not yet in this spec or implementation, but it needs to be added.

I am concerned about planning for automatic convergence of all resources.  The last time I asked about this, I was told that automatic convergence would first be implemented for scaling group members only, with automatic convergence for all resources happening later if at all.  I recall Angus' skepticism about automatically converging all resources, on the grounds that this would remove a level of control that users value.

I think that if Heat offers only a recreate webhook per member then the user will still have to code up a lot of boilerplate for the common case of reacting to determinations made for a Neutron PoolMember.  I completely agree that this should not be the only kind of health maintenance supported, but I think that maintaining health as determined for Neutron PoolMembers should be available with succinct template source --- both now and into the grand and glorious future.  Introducing this concept now does not prevent us from later introducing something that is more general but requires more boilerplate to use in common cases.

parents.subject: Add a file folder 'juno' for juno bp-specs

commit.subject: Adding Optional Health to OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup
commit.message:
Adding Optional Health to OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup

The motivation for introducing this change is the lack of positive
affirmation in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/121824/ that there
will be a reasonable transition period during which both
``OS::Heat::HARestarter`` and some newer better alternative are
available.  You can also see in the discussion in
http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/heat/2014/heat.2014-10-01-12.01.log.html
a desire to keep open the possibility that HARestarter will be removed
without a 1 release transition period.  The proposed change is to
introduce, at least 1 release before HARestarter is removed, a wrapper
that (a) obscures the use of HARestarter, (b) has an interface that is
narrow enough that we are confident that it will be reasonable to
implement in the not clearly seen future, (c) has enough functionality
that current users of HARestarer can use the wrapper instead.  In
addition to those three sharp criteria, there is also a desire to make
the wrapper be something that we would be comfortable with users using
indefinitely, not just to smooth over a transition away from
HARestarter.  This enables current users to switch to using the
wrapper over a transtion period of at least 1 release before
HARestarter is removed.  Once users have made this transition, we can
remove HARestarter and change the implementation behind the wrapper
simultaneously without disturbing users.

This is the spec for
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/autoscaling-healthy-group

Change-Id: I9a76b5e7610c7f5b6f798ea7e03788f8a731157e

parents.subject: Add a file folder 'juno' for juno bp-specs

commit.subject: Adding Optional Health to OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup
commit.message:
Adding Optional Health to OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup

Currently it is possible to write a Heat template that prescribes a
set of virtual resources with health maintenance, using the health
determinations made by Neutron's LBaaS.  While it is possible, it is
ugly.  The user is required to write a bunch of mechanism for each
thing that the user wants maintained.  There is no way for a user or a
cloud operator to write a template resource (formerly known as a
provider template) that implements this abstraction.  In contrast,
some other IaaS platforms have health maintenance as a built-in part
of the functionality of their scaling groups.  The proposed change is
to generalize ``OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup`` so that it can optionally
maintain member health as determined by LBaaS.  Note that LBaaS has
health checking functionality that does not require any actual
application traffic to be load balanced.  The goal here is not to
attempt fully general health maintenance, only to cover common cases
--- with an interface that we think is reasonable to use and does not
paint ourselves into a corner regarding future implementations.  It
just so happens that all of the users I know to be wanting health
maintenance will be satisfied with this generalization of
``OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup`` --- and be happy to use it instead of
repeating a bunch of mechanism using ``OS::Heat::HARestarter`` and/or
other stuff --- supposing the relevant schedulers do not keep putting
guests on broken hosts (which is really a separate problem).

This is the spec for
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/autoscaling-healthy-group

Change-Id: I9a76b5e7610c7f5b6f798ea7e03788f8a731157e

parents.subject: Add a file folder 'juno' for juno bp-specs

commit.subject: Spec for AutoScalingGroup with Health Maintenance
commit.message:
Spec for AutoScalingGroup with Health Maintenance

To cope with lack of promise of reasonable transition period when
HARestarter is removed, defines OS::Heat::AutoScalingHealthyGroup, to
be a subclass of OS::Heat::AutoScalingGroup that adds health
maintenance for members based on health as determined by an
OS::Neutron::Pool. This is implementable now, and should be
implementable when OS::Heat::HARestarter is replaced with something
else.

This spec follows a revised approach that has no dependency (unlike
the first approach).

Change-Id: I9a76b5e7610c7f5b6f798ea7e03788f8a731157e

Hi Christian,

Please verify the patch.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

The code looks fine, but test/functional/test_container.py:TestContainer.test_PUT_bad_metadata must be updated. Currently it fails to clear the old metadata and thus deservedly fails as soon as it tries to add MAX_META_COUNT of new metadata.

Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

This makes container metadata updates twice as expensive (two requests to backends) as well as adds an unsynchronized read-modify-write operation. Please don't do that. Check it at the container server where you have incoming and existing metadata together already.

The patch needs unit tests for the new behavior.

This patch doesn't address limiting the overall serialized-metadata size either; a user can still rapidly churn through metadata (add set 1, then add set 2 and delete set 1, then add set 3 and delete set 2, ...) and make the stored metadata huge. Technically, the size is still bounded because metadata tombstones *do* get reaped after reclaim_age (default 1 week), but that bound is so large that it's useless.

commit.subject: Use reveal.js instead of slidy
commit.message:
Use reveal.js instead of slidy

There are a lot of neat features in reveal.js - and Florian likes it a
lot. It's got the ability to do a second-screen speaker notes if you
WANT to set up the stuff for that - but also it can just be a
single-page html like our current stuff. The markup is almost identical
- other than repacing <div class="slide"> with <section>

HOWEVER - this mainly started out as an afternoon experiment just to
poke at reveal.js. I don't think it's important that we do this - but I
thought I'd share with folks.

Change-Id: I4927d08b98021042f28bcf38a2493d6c10349d97

commit.subject: WIP Add a "reviews please" msg to welcome_message
commit.message:
WIP Add a "reviews please" msg to welcome_message

NB - this is a WIP, for discussion :)

The purpose is to encourage new contributors, who
appear to be getting the 'code' side of the process, but have not
contributed any reviews.

* change is_newbie to number_of_patches, to allow better reuse
* Modify post_message to support multiple message types
* add number_of_reviews to determine number of reviews
* add logic to post a message if owner has 5 patches but 0 reviews

Change-Id: I7f24d662025c298e05b008ee5327e428cb909b64

parents.subject: Enable object system metadata on PUTs

commit.subject: Enable updateable object sysmeta
commit.message:
Enable updateable object sysmeta

** Work In Progress **

Make it so that individual items of object sysmeta
can be updated with a fast-POST request (unlike user
metadata which is replaced as a whole).

There is a probe test that simulates sysmeta merge during
POST and rsync replication after object server 'failure':

nosetests test/probe/test_object_metadata_replication.py:Test.test_updatable_sysmeta

Changes:

- With fast POST, read existing sysmeta, update individual items
and write merged results to new meta file

- To cope with concurrent POSTs and replicated meta files, only
delete meta files when content has been read/merged/written
to new meta file

- Read all meta files when opening diskfile, so after replication
sysmeta is consistent across cluster

- This can result in multiple meta files after
failure conditions/replication with rsync, so merge during
replication too.

- Meta files with same timestamp could have different content
on different servers due to failures, so append md5 hash to
meta file name (yuk)

Work still left to do includes:

- prevent user meta being wiped when sysmeta is POSTed (introduce
X-Preserve-User-Meta header?)

- find a better (more concise) meta file naming scheme

- ssync

- more tests needed

Spec: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/109314/
Change-Id: I149ac2da7150e50aaf6b72e9d7097c52005613d4

Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. The more you
    participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also
    notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster
    your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others
    and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a
    great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Gerrit_Workflow

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

We usually add Closes-Bug: xxxxx in commit message, so the review system will help to close the corresponding Launchpad bug automatically after the submit is merged.Please follow this guide(https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritWorkflow#Committing_Changes) to write commit message.
